Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Automatic Network Trace Analysis and Clustering

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principle outcome of this work was a fruitful research collaboration between researchers in the Computer Science Systems Laboratory at the University of Colorado, Boulder and the WAND Research Group at the University of Waikato in New Zealand. In particular, the PI of this project, Caleb Phillips, worked with researchers in the WAND group to collect a large and novel corpus of measurements of the perforance and propagation of wireless transmitters in rural environments. This data set has been subsequently used in work that has produced important results related to the quantifying the accuracy of wireless path loss prediction models [1,2] and is being used in ongoing research related to error modeling for wireless network connections.

In addition to this work, close ties were formed between the research groups that have enabled collaboration in other areas including wireless coverage mapping visualization strategies, anomoly detection in wired networks. During the term of the fellowship, connections were also formed to researchers at other top universities in New Zealand, including but not limited to the University of Canterbury in Christchurch New Zealand, and the University of Auckland in Auckland, New Zealand.

[1] Caleb Phillips, Scott Raynel, Jamie Curtis, Sam Bartels, Douglas Sicker, Dirk Grunwald and Tony McGregor. The Efficacy of Path Loss Models for Fixed Rural Wireless Links. Passive and Active Measurement Conference 2011 (PAM 2011). Atlanta, Georgia. March 20-22, 2011.

[2] Caleb Phillips, Douglas Sicker, and Dirk Grunwald. Bounding the Practical Error of Path Loss Models in Urban Environments. IEEE Dynamic Spectrum Access Networks 2011 (DySPAN 2011). Aachen, Germany. May 3-6, 2011.


Last Modified: 09/30/2011
Modified by: Caleb T Phillips
